title: Math Document
description: A structured math document in a custom JSON format

oneOf.description: A statement introducing a new variable with given value, type and/or property.
A statement introducing a new variable and saying that **some** value of this variable is as required (i.e., an existence statement).
A mathematical assumption being made. In case this is a variable or structure being introduced, use a 'let' statement.
A mathematical term being defined. In case a definition is being used, use 'assert' or 'theorem' instead.
A mathematical statement whose proof is a straightforward consequence of given and known results following some method.
A mathematical theorem, with a list of hypotheses and a conclusion.
A mathematical problem, with a statement and an answer.
A proof by cases or proof by induction, with a list of cases.
A proof by induction, with a base case and an induction step.
A proof by contradiction, with an assumption and a proof of the contradiction.
An equation, inequality, short calculation etc.
Conclude a claim obtained from the steps so far. This is typically the final statement of a proof giving the conclusion of the theorem.
A remark or comment that is NOT MATHEMATICAL, instead being for motivation, attention, sectioning etc.

let_statement.description: A statement introducing a new variable with given value, type and/or property.

variable.description: The variable being defined (use `<anonymous>` if there is no name such as in `We have a group structure on S`)

value.description: (OPTIONAL) The value of the variable being defined

kind.description: (OPTIONAL) The type of the variable, such as `real number`, `function from S to T`, `element of G` etc.

properties.description: (OPTIONAL) Specific properties of the variable beyond the type

some_statement.description: A statement introducing a new variable and saying that **some** value of this variable is as required (i.e., an existence statement). This is possibly with given type and/or property. This corresponds to statements like 'for some integer `n` ...' or 'There exists an integer `n` ....'

variable.description: The variable being defined (use `<anonymous>` if there is no name such as in `We have a group structure on S`)

kind.description: (OPTIONAL) The type of the variable, such as `real number`, `function from S to T`, `element of G` etc.

properties.description: (OPTIONAL) Specific properties of the variable beyond the type

assume_statement.description: A mathematical assumption being made. In case this is a variable or structure being introduced, use a 'let' statement.

def_statement.description: A mathematical term being defined. In case a definition is being used, use 'assert' or 'theorem' instead.

name.description: (OPTIONAL) The name of the theorem, lemma or claim.

assert_statement.description: A mathematical statement whose proof is a straightforward consequence of given and known results following some method.

claim.description: The mathematical claim being asserted, NOT INCLUDING proofs, justifications or results used. The claim should be purely a logical statement which is the *consequence* obtained.

proof_method.description: (OPTIONAL) The method used to prove the claim. This could be a direct proof, proof by contradiction, proof by induction, etc. this should be a single phrase or a fairly simple sentence; if a longer justification is needed break the step into smaller steps. If the method is deduction from a result, use the 'deduced_using' field

deduced_from_results.description: (OPTIONAL) A list of elements of type `deduced_from`.

calculate.description: (OPTIONAL) An equation, inequality, short calculation etc.

missing_proofs.description: (OPTIONAL) A list of elements of type `missing`.

errors.description: (OPTIONAL) A list of elements of type `error`.

deduced_from.description: A deduction of a mathematical result from assumptions or previously known results.

result_used.description: An assumption or previously known results from which the deduction is made. If more than one result is used, list them in the 'deductions' field as separate `deduction` objects. If the result used needs justification, have a separate `assert` object earlier.

proved_earlier.description: Whether the statement from which deduction has been proved earlier IN THIS DOCUMENT. Answer `true` or `false` (answer `false` if a result from the mathematical literature is being invoked).

calculate_choice.description: An equation, inequality, short calculation etc.

inline_calculation.description: A simple calculation or computation written as a single line.

calculation_sequence.description: A list of elements of type `calculation_step`.

calculation_step.description: A step, typically an equality or inequality, in a calculation or computation.

missing.description: A Â problem that need to be solved or results that need to be proved to complete the proof. Standard results/criteria may be omitted from the proof: include them in the 'deduced_from' field.

error.description: An error in a proof or calculation. Report only actual errors, with missing steps reported in the 'missing' field.

theorem_statement.description: A mathematical theorem, with a list of hypotheses and a conclusion.

hypothesis.description: a JSON list of data and assumptions, i.e., **let** and **assume** statements

proved.description: Whether the theorem has been proved, either here or earlier or by citing the literature.

name.description: (OPTIONAL) The name of the theorem, lemma or claim.

proof.description: (OPTIONAL) A proof of a lemma, theorem or claim, having the same structure as (the value for) a `math_document`.

ref.description: (OPTIONAL) A reference where the result has been previously proved.

cite.description: (OPTIONAL) A citation of a result from the mathematical literature which gives the proof.

missing_proofs.description: (OPTIONAL) A list of elements of type `missing`.

errors.description: (OPTIONAL) A list of elements of type `error`.

problem_statement.description: A mathematical problem, with a statement and an answer.

solved.description: Whether the problem has been solved.

proof.description: (OPTIONAL) A proof of a lemma, theorem or claim, having the same structure as (the value for) a `math_document`.

missing_proofs.description: (OPTIONAL) A list of elements of type `missing`.

errors.description: (OPTIONAL) A list of elements of type `error`.

cases_statement.description: A proof by cases or proof by induction, with a list of cases.

split_kind.description: one of 'implication_direction' (for two sides of an 'iff' implication), 'match' (for pattern matching), 'condition' (if based on a condition being true or false) and 'groups' (for more complex cases).

on.description: The variable or expression on which the cases are being done. Write 'implication direction' for an 'iff' statement.

proof_cases.description: A list of elements of type `case`.

exhaustiveness.description: (OPTIONAL) Proof that the cases are exhaustive, similar to (the value for) 'math_document'.

missing_proofs.description: (OPTIONAL) A list of elements of type `missing`.

errors.description: (OPTIONAL) A list of elements of type `error`.

case.description: A case in a proof by cases or proof by induction.

condition.description: The case condition or pattern; for induction one of 'base' or 'induction-step'; for a side of an 'iff' statement write the claim being proved (i.e., the statement `P => Q` or `Q => P`).

proof.description: A proof of a lemma, theorem or claim, having the same structure as (the value for) a `math_document`.

missing_proofs.description: (OPTIONAL) A list of elements of type `missing`.

errors.description: (OPTIONAL) A list of elements of type `error`.

induction_statement.description: A proof by induction, with a base case and an induction step.

on.description: The variable or expression on which induction is being done.

proof_cases.description: A list of elements of type `case`.

contradiction_statement.description: A proof by contradiction, with an assumption and a proof of the contradiction.

assumption.description: The assumption being made to be contradicted.

proof.description: The proof of the contradiction given the assumption.

missing_proofs.description: (OPTIONAL) A list of elements of type `missing`.

errors.description: (OPTIONAL) A list of elements of type `error`.

calculate_statement.description: An equation, inequality, short calculation etc.

conclude_statement.description: Conclude a claim obtained from the steps so far. This is typically the final statement of a proof giving the conclusion of the theorem.

missing_proofs.description: (OPTIONAL) A list of elements of type `missing`.

errors.description: (OPTIONAL) A list of elements of type `error`.

remark_statement.description: A remark or comment that is NOT MATHEMATICAL, instead being for motivation, attention, sectioning etc.
